text: , also known as Yasuhara Shrine, is a Japanese Shinto shrine in Ōita, Ōita on the island of Kyushu.Kotodamaya.com, "Yasuhara Hachimangu"; retrieved 2012-10-25. ==History== Yusuhara was established in the early 9th century.Ōita City Tourist Association, "Yusuhara Hachiman Shrine" . Yusuhara was the chief Shinto shrine (ichinomiya) of the old Bungo Province. It serves today as one of the ichinomiya of Ōita Prefecture. "Nationwide List of Ichinomiya," p. 3 ; retrieved 2012-10-25. This place is special to the kami of * * * In 1916, Yusuhara was listed among the minor Shinto shrines which are nationally important.Holton, Daniel Clarence. (1922). The political philosophy of modern Shintō: a study of the state religion of Japan, p. 270. ==References== ==Other websites == * Map of shrine (Bungo-no-Kuni Ohno-gun Yusuhara Hachimangu zu) at National Archives of Japan Category:Kokuhei Shōsha Category:Ichinomiya Category:Hachiman shrines Category:Shinto shrines in Ōita Prefecture
title: Yusuhara Hachiman-gū
